High blood pressure (also called hypertension) can lead to serious problems like heart attacks or strokes. But lifestyle changes and blood pressure medicines can help you stay healthy.

sections.title: Check if you're at risk of high blood pressure
paragraphs: High blood pressure is very common, especially in older adults. There are usually no symptoms, so you may not realise you have it.

sections.title: Non-urgent advice:Get your blood pressure checked at a pharmacy or GP surgery if:
paragraphs: Some pharmacies may charge for a blood pressure check.
Some workplaces also offer blood pressure checks. Check with your employer.

sections.title: Free pharmacy checks for over 40s
paragraphs: Many pharmacies offer free blood pressure checks for people aged 40 or over.
Find a pharmacy that offers free blood pressure checks

sections.title: Symptoms of high blood pressure
paragraphs: High blood pressure does not usually cause any symptoms.

But the only way to find out if you have high blood pressure is to get your blood pressure checked.

sections.title: Urgent advice:Get help from NHS 111 if:
paragraphs: You can call 111 orget help from 111 online.

sections.title: Immediate action required:Call 999 if:
paragraphs: You could be having a heart attack. Call 999 straight away as you need immediate treatment in hospital.
Do not drive yourself to A&E.
The person you speak to at 999 will give you advice about what to do.

sections.title: Risks of having high blood pressure
paragraphs: If your blood pressure is too high, it puts extra strain on your blood vessels, heart and other organs, such as your brain, kidneys and eyes.
If it's not treated, it can increase your risk of serious conditions such as:
Lowering your blood pressure even a small amount can help reduce your risk of these problems.

sections.title: How you can help lower your blood pressure
paragraphs: Healthy lifestyle changes can help lower your blood pressure.

sections.title: Do
paragraphs: have a healthy, balanced diet
exercise regularly – aim to do at least 150 minutes of exercise a week
lose weight if you're overweight

sections.title: Don’t
paragraphs: do not eat too much salt – avoid salty food or adding salt to your meals
do not drink too much alcohol – avoid drinking more than 14 alcohol units a week on a regular basis
do not drink too much caffeine – drinks high in caffeine include coffee, tea and cola
do not smoke

sections.title: NHS help to get healthy
paragraphs: NHS Better Health has free tools and support to help you lose weight, get active, quit smoking and drink less.
Visit the NHS Better Health website

sections.title: Medicines for high blood pressure
paragraphs: A GP will usually prescribe medicine for high blood pressure if:
There are lots of different medicines for high blood pressure. The medicine recommended for you depends on things like how high your blood pressure is, your age and your ethnicity.
Most blood pressure medicines are taken as tablets once a day. You may need to take more than 1 medicine to keep your blood pressure under control.
